daterangePicker.buttonBorderWidth: Defines the stroke weight or border width for outlining all buttons within this date range picker.
daterangePicker.buttonBorderStyle: Defines the stroke style for outlining all buttons within this date range picker.
datagrid.data: Defines the table that the data grid uses as a data source.
datagrid.rowHeight: Defines the height of this data grid's rows, in pixels.
datagrid.rowBackground: Defines the fill for the first group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBackground2: Defines the fill for the second group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBorder: Defines the stroke color or border image for outlining the first group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBorderWidth: Defines the stroke weight or border width for outlining the first group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBorderStyle: Defines the stroke style for outlining the first group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBorder2: Defines the stroke color or border image for outlining the second group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBorder2Width: Defines the stroke weight or border width for outlining the second group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBorder2Style: Defines the stroke style for outlining the second group of alternating rows.
datagrid.rowBackgroundSelect: Defines the fill for the selected rows. Only works when selection is enabled for the data grid.
datagrid.rowBorderSelect: Defines the stroke color or border image for outlining for outlining selected rows. Only works when selection is enabled for the data grid.
datagrid.rowBorderWidthSelect: Defines the stroke weight or border width for outlining selected rows. Only works when selection is enabled for the data grid.
datagrid.rowBorderStyleSelect: Defines the stroke style for outlining selected rows. Only works when selection is enabled for the data grid.
datagrid.rowBackgroundFocus:
Defines the fill for the row in the data grid that is in focus.

When the user mouses over the row, the hovered row properties override the focused row properties.
datagrid.rowBorderFocus:
Defines the stroke color or border image for outlining the row in the data grid that is in focus.

When the user mouses over the row, the hovered row properties override the focused row properties.
datagrid.rowBorderWidthFocus:
Defines the stroke weight or border width for outlining the row in the data grid that is in focus.

When the user mouses over the row, the hovered row properties override the focused row properties.
datagrid.rowBorderStyleFocus:
Defines the stroke style for outlining the row in the data grid that is in focus.

When the user mouses over the row, the hovered row properties override the focused row properties.
datagrid.rowBackgroundHover: Defines the fill for the row that the user mouses over.
datagrid.rowBorderHover: Defines the stroke color or border image for outlining the row that the user mouses over.
datagrid.rowBorderWidthHover: Defines the stroke weight or border width for outlining the row that the user mouses over.
datagrid.rowBorderStyleHover: Defines the stroke style for outlining the row that the user mouses over.
datagrid.defaultCellKeepEqualPaddings: Links all four padding editors so that their values are equal.
datagrid.gridMode: Defines whether the Property Inspector displays property editing options for horizontal gridlines, vertical gridlines, or both. Changing this property does not reset any gridline properties.
datagrid.hGridWidth:
Defines the stroke weight for this data grid's horizontal gridlines.

To define the line between the top row of data and the header, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagrid.hGridStroke:
Defines the stroke style for this data grid's horizontal gridlines.

To define the line between the top row of data and the header, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagrid.hGridColor:
Defines the stroke color for this data grid's horizontal gridlines.

To define the line between the top row of data and the header, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagrid.vGridWidth:
Defines the stroke weight for the vertical lines that divide columns.

To define the lines between column headers, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagrid.vGridStroke:
Defines the stroke style for the vertical lines that divide columns.

To define the lines between column headers, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagrid.vGridColor:
Defines the stroke color for the vertical lines that divide columns.

To define the lines between column headers, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagrid.headerHeight: Defines the height of the header in pixels. A value of Auto makes the header height depend on its content. A value of zero hides the header.
datagrid.headerBackground: Defines the fill for this data grid's header.
datagrid.headerBorder: Defines the stroke color or border image for outlining this data grid's header.
datagrid.headerBorderWidth: Defines the stroke weight or border width for outlining this data grid's header.
datagrid.headerBorderStyle: Defines the stroke style for outlining this data grid's header.
datagrid.vHeaderGridWidth: Defines the stroke weight for the vertical lines that divide the column headers.
datagrid.vHeaderGridStroke: Defines the stroke style for the vertical lines that divide the column headers.
datagrid.vHeaderGridColor: Defines the stroke color for the vertical lines that divide the column headers.
datagrid.columnFilter: Specifies the columns for a filter, as a comma-separated list of table column names. Use the Filter Type property to specify whether these columns are shown in this data grid or hidden from it.
datagrid.columnFilterType:
Specifies how this filter handles the listed columns.

Whitelist
Only the listed columns are shown in this data grid.

Blacklist
The listed columns are hidden from this data grid.
datagrid.sortOrder:
Specifies whether the data is sorted in ascending or descending order.

To change whether the data is treated as strings or numbers when sorted, open the dataflow for this data grid and edit the sort block.
datagrid.sortColumn: Defines which column to use to sort the data, using the table column name. Only works if the column has the Sortable property enabled.
datagridRows.grid.rowHeight: Defines the height in pixels of each data grid row.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellFontFamily: Defines the font color for this element.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellFontColor: Defines the font color for this element.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellFontSize: Defines the font size for this element.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellFontWeight: Specifies whether the text in this element is bold.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellFontStyle: Specifies whether the text in this element is italicized.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellPaddingTop: Defines a number of pixels of space between the top container boundary and the topmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellPaddingBott: Defines a number of pixels of space between the bottom container boundary and the bottommost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellPaddingLeft: Defines a number of pixels of space between the left container boundary and the leftmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellPaddingRigh: Defines a number of pixels of space between the right container boundary and the rightmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellKeepEqualPa: Links all four padding editors so that their values are equal.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellAlign: Specifies whether the content in the rows is left-justified, centered, or right-justified.
datagridRows.grid.defaultCellVerticalAli: Specifies whether the content in the rows is positioned at the top, middle, or bottom of the container.
datagridRows.grid.gridMode: Defines whether the Property Inspector displays property editing options for horizontal gridlines, vertical gridlines, or both. Changing this property does not reset any gridline properties.
datagridRows.grid.hGridWidth:
Defines the stroke weight for this data grid's horizontal gridlines.

To define the line between the top row of data and the header, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagridRows.grid.hGridStroke:
Defines the stroke style for this data grid's horizontal gridlines.

To define the line between the top row of data and the header, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagridRows.grid.hGridColor:
Defines the stroke color for this data grid's horizontal gridlines.

To define the line between the top row of data and the header, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagridRows.grid.vGridWidth:
Defines the stroke weight for the vertical lines that divide columns.

To define the lines between column headers, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagridRows.grid.vGridStroke:
Defines the stroke style for the vertical lines that divide columns.

To define the lines between column headers, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagridRows.grid.vGridColor:
Defines the stroke color for the vertical lines that divide columns.

To define the lines between column headers, use the header's Fill and Stroke properties.
datagridHeader.grid.headerFontFamily:
Specifies the font for this element.

To add a new font to your project and use it for this property:

  1. If you have not already done so, right-click the root folder for your project, and add a new folder named fonts
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop-down menu for this property.
datagridHeader.grid.headerFontColor: Defines the font color for this element.
datagridHeader.grid.headerFontSize: Defines the font size for this element.
datagridHeader.grid.headerFontStyle: Specifies whether the text in this element is italicized.
datagridHeader.grid.headerFontWeight: Specifies whether the text in this element is bold.
datagridHeader.grid.headerAlign: Specifies whether the content in the header is left-justified, centered, or right-justified.
datagridHeader.grid.headerVerticalAlign: Specifies whether the content in the header is positioned at the top, middle, or bottom of the container.
datagridHeader.grid.headerPaddingLeft: Defines a number of pixels of space between the left container boundary and the leftmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridHeader.grid.headerPaddingRight: Defines a number of pixels of space between the right container boundary and the rightmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridHeader.grid.headerPaddingTop: Defines a number of pixels of space between the top container boundary and the topmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridHeader.grid.headerPaddingBottom: Defines a number of pixels of space between the bottom container boundary and the bottommost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.
datagridHeader.grid.keepEqualHeaderPaddi: Links all four padding editors so that their values are equal.
datagridHeader.grid.vHeaderGridColor: Defines the color for the vertical lines that divide the column headers.
datagridHeader.grid.vHeaderGridWidth: Defines the stroke weight for the vertical lines that divide the column headers.
datagridHeader.grid.vHeaderGridStroke: Defines the stroke style for the vertical lines that divide the column headers.
datagridHeader.grid.headerHeight: Defines the height of the header in pixels. A value of Auto makes the header height follow the size of its content. A value of zero hides the header.
chart.dataTipMode:
Defines datatip behavior.

None
No datatips are displayed.

Single
When the user mouses over a data point, a datatip is displayed. Only one datatip is displayed at a time.

Multiple
When the user mouses over a data point, a datatip is displayed. If points from multiple series exist at the moused-over position, multiple datatips are displayed. Only one datatip is displayed per series.
chart.innerRadius: Defines the radius for the blank area in the center of the pie chart. This blank area is useful for creating multilevel pie charts and doughnut charts.
chart.outerRadius:
Defines the radius of this pie chart, as a percentage of the radius of the largest pie chart that would fit. This depends on container size.

If the Reduce Outer Radius property is TRUE, then the radius size might be automatically reduced in order to fit labels or other elements.
chart.reduceOuterRadius:
Defines whether the pie chart radius shrinks automatically in order to fit labels or other elements.

TRUE
The pie chart radius might be smaller than that determined by the Outer Radius property, in order to fit labels or other elements.

FALSE
The pie chart size is determined by the Outer Radius property only.
rawSvgRepeater.data: Defines the table that controls the SVG repeater. The SVG element will repeat once for each row in the table. Table columns can be used to represent attributes of the SVG element, such as style or coordinates.
rawSvgRepeater.svgItem:
Defines the code for an SVG element to be repeated by this repeater.

Example
<rect width="30" height="30" fill="green" x="[v1]00" y="[v2]"></rect>

This example creates a repeating green rectangle SVG element. The SVG element appears at the x- and y-coordinates defined by columns v1 and v2 of the linked table. In the case of the x-coordinate, the table cell values are multiplied by 100 by concatenating two zeroes.
rawSvgRepeater.svgDefs:
Defines the <defs> element for the repeated SVG element.

Example
<style>rect{fill:green;stroke:black;}</style>

This example defines a style for the repeated SVG rectangle. The style includes a green fill and a black border stroke.
rawSvgRepeater.dataTipSymbol: Defines the symbol that appears as a datatip when mousing over an instance of the SVG in this repeater.
scaleTicks.ticksPlacement: Specifies whether the ticks are positioned on the inside, outside, or center of the circle or line that defines the scale.
scaleTicks.majorTickStroke: Defines the stroke color of the major ticks.
scaleTicks.majorTickStrokeWidth: Defines the stroke weight of each major tick.
scaleTicks.majorTicksPercentLength: Defines the length of each major tick, as a pixel value or a percentage. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle’s radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of half the container width.
scaleTicks.minorTicksCount: Defines the number of minor ticks between each consecutive pair of major ticks.
scaleTicks.minorTicksPercentLength: Defines the length of each minor tick, as a pixel value or a percentage. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle’s radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of half the container width.
scaleLabels.showMinMaxOnly: Specifies whether the labels for the minimum and maximum of the scale are the only two labels that appear. This property overrides the Labels Count property.
scaleLabels.percentTextSize: Defines the height of the scale labels, as a pixel value or percentage. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle's radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of half the container width.
scaleLabels.justify: Specifies whether the labels appear on the inside, outside, or center of the circle or line that defines the scale.
scaleTrack.percentStartThickness: Defines the thickness of the scale track at its start, as a pixel or percentage value. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle’s radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of the entire container width.
scaleTrack.percentEndThickness: Defines the thickness of the scale track at its end, as a pixel or percentage value. For circular scales, a percentage is a portion of the circle’s radius. For linear scales, a percentage is a portion of the entire container width.
scaleTrack.placement: Specifies whether the track is positioned on the inside, outside, or center of the circle or line that defines the scale.
rangeFormInput.ticks: Defines values where ticks appear on the range selector, as a list of comma-separated values.
listFormElement.selectedIndex: Sets or returns the index of the currently selected list element. A value of 0 indicates the top element in the list.
listFormElement.showArrow: Determines whether an arrow graphic appears in the component, indicating a drop-down list.
listFormElement.arrowImage: Specifies a custom arrow graphic that appears if Show Arrow is enabled. If you don't specify an image, a default graphic is used.
listFormElement.options: Defines the list of options for this list element, as comma-separated values.
listFormElement.optionFontFamily:
Defines the font for the option list. Not supported in all browsers.

To add a new font to your project and use it for this property:

  1. If you have not already done so, right-click the root folder for your project, and add a new folder named fonts.
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop-down menu for this property.
listFormElement.optionFontSize: Defines the font size for the option list. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.optionColor: Defines the font color for the option list. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.optionBackground: Defines the fill for the option list. Not supported in all browsers.
fileFormInput.binaryMode: Sets whether the file content is displayed as a string or as binary.
fileFormInput.file: Displays the content of the selected file as a string or binary.
fileFormInput.open: Opens the browser file chooser. To set the file chooser to open in certain circumstances, you can bind data or properties to this button, or click it as part of a recorded action.
fileFormInput.accept:
Specifies the file formats that are accepted by this file chooser.

Enter one or more of the following values separated by commas:

  • .png, .jpg, .gif, etc. – Files of the format specified.
  • audio/* – All sound files.
  • video/* – All video files.
  • image/* – All image files.
  • media_type/* – Replace media_type with any valid media type, to accept all formats within that type. Look at IANA Media Types for a complete list of standard media types.
axis.axisMinimum: Returns the minimum of the axis range. This is a read-only property, so changing it manually does nothing.
axis.axisMaximum: Returns the maximum of the axis range. This is a read-only property, so changing it manually does nothing.
axis.assignedMinorInterval: Defines the interval between each consecutive pair of minor ticks, in the units of the axis.
axis.dgDataProvider: Defines the table that feeds data to this category axis.
axis.categoryField: Defines the table column that contains category names.
axis.dgCategoryOrder: Defines the order of the categories on this axis, as a list of comma-separated values.
axis.compareMode:
Defines the Compare Mode of this axis. Use a Compare Mode when you want to overlay data for different dates and times.

To configure your chart to start using Compare Mode:

  1. Insert a blank chart.
  2. Drag your metric onto the chart, and click OK.
  3. Drag the same metric onto the chart a second time. Check "Use Existing Axis" for both axes, and click OK.
  4. Open dataflow for the chart. Select a timeRange for each of the two loadHistory blocks. Ensure that the two ranges are the same range type. For example, both ranges could be be one day long, or both could be one week long.

Now you are ready to use the Compare Mode property. There are six choices:

None
Series from different dates and times are not aligned.

Hour
Times of day are aligned, so you can compare midnight with midnight.

Day
Date ranges are aligned, so you can compare "day one" from different ranges.

Week
Days of the week are aligned, so you can compare Mondays with Mondays.

MonthDays of the month are aligned, so you can compare firsts of the month.

Year
Days of the year are aligned, so you can compare January first with January first.
lineSeries.symbol:
Specifies the symbol to use for custom markers.

To use a symbol from this project, enter the name of the symbol.

To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol

.
areaSeries.symbol:
Specifies the symbol to use for custom markers.

To use a symbol from this project, enter the name of the symbol.

To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol

.
columnSeries.dgOffset:
Moves columns to the left or right by a portion of the maximum column width. The maximum column width is equal to 1/n of the plot area width, with n being the total number of columns for the chart.

A value of −0.1 moves the columns to the left by 10% of this maximum width. A value of 0.1 moves the columns to the right by 10% of this maximum width.

This Property is related to the Column Width Ratio property for the chart. Column Width Ratio determines the width of each column in the chart as a percentage of the maximum column width.

Example
The Column Width Ratio is 60%, and there are two series. You want to offset the columns in series 1 by 10% of their width. For Column Offset, use the value (0.6 / 2) * 0.1 = 0.03.
columnSeries.symbol:
Specifies the symbol to use for custom columns.

To use a symbol from this project, enter the name of the symbol.

To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol

.
barSeries.symbol:
Specifies the symbol to use for custom bars.

To use a symbol from this project, enter the name of the symbol.

To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol

.
pieSeries.dgWedgeLabel: Configures the text displayed in wedge labels for this series. Use the same tags you would use for a datatip.
pieSeries.radialStroke: Defines the stroke color for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.radialStrokeWidth: Defines the stroke weight for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.radialStrokeStyle: Defines the stroke style for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.calloutGap: Defines the amount of empty space, in pixels, that is added to the gap between the edge of the pie and the edge of the labels. Does not define the entire gap, but rather the amount that is added to the default gap. A negative value makes the gap smaller than the default.
pieSeries.calloutStroke: Defines the stroke color for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.calloutStrokeWidth: Defines the stroke weight for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.calloutStrokeStyle: Defines the stroke style for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.labelPosition:
Defines the position of the labels.

None
There are no labels.

Outside
Labels are positioned for each pie wedge, near the outer edge of the pie series. Labels might be inside or outside the wedges, depending on the outer radius of the series. 

Callout
Labels are positioned outside of the chart, with callout lines.

Inside
Labels are positioned inside each pie wedge.

Inside with Callout
Labels are positioned inside each pie wedge when possible. If a label can't be positioned inside, it is positioned outside of the chart, with a callout line.
pieSeries.explodeRadius: Defines the distance that the series is exploded, as a percentage of the outer radius of the chart. Wedges move away from the center by this distance without changing their shape.
pieSeries.dgFills:
Specify colors for the pie wedges in this series. Click Add to add a color. Click on a color to edit it.

Colors are used in order, with the top color corresponding to the top row of table data.

The Color Field property overrides this property.
pieSeries.colorField:
Specifies the table column that contains data from which to determine wedge colors. The following formats are supported:

  • #EEE – any shortened, three-digit hexadecimal color string, including the # symbol.
  • #FF00FF – any hexadecimal color string, including the # symbol.
  • rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5) – any RGBA color string, including "rgba" and the parentheses.
Alternatively, you can specify colors in the Property Inspector by expanding Wedge Fills.
gridlines.gridDirection: Defines which gridlines are displayed in the plotting area of the chart. You can choose to have horizontal only, vertical only, both, or none.
gridlines.horizontalAlternateFill: Defines the second of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between horizontal gridlines.
gridlines.horizontalFill: Defines the first of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between horizontal gridlines.
gridlines.horizontalStroke: Defines the stroke color for horizontal gridlines.
gridlines.horizontalStrokeWidth: Defines the stroke weight for horizontal gridlines.
gridlines.horizontalStrokeStyle: Defines the stroke style for horizontal gridlines. A stroke weight greater than 0 overrides a stroke style of None.
gridlines.horizontalTickAligned:
Defines where horizontal gridlines are placed.

TRUE
Horizontal gridlines are positioned at major ticks.

FALSE
Horizontal gridlines are positioned halfway between major ticks.
gridlines.verticalAlternateFill: Defines the second of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalFill: Defines the first of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalStroke: Defines the stroke color for vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalStrokeWidth: Defines the stroke weight for vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalStrokeStyle: Defines the stroke style for vertical gridlines. A stroke weight greater than 0 overrides a stroke style of None.
gridlines.verticalTickAligned:
Defines where vertical gridlines are placed.

TRUE
Vertical gridlines are positioned at major ticks.

FALSE
Vertical gridlines are positioned halfway between major ticks.
gridlines.plottedAreaX: Returns the view x-coordinate at the left edge of the plotted area. This is a read-only property, so changing it manually does nothing.
gridlines.plottedAreaY: Returns the view y-coordinate at the top edge of the plotted area. This is a read-only property, so changing it manually does nothing.
gridlines.plottedAreaWidth: Returns the width of the plot area in pixels. This is a read-only property, so changing it manually does nothing.
gridlines.plottedAreaHeight: Returns the height of the plot area in pixels. This is a read-only property, so changing it manually does nothing.
string.value: Sets and returns the value of this String block.
number.value: Sets and returns the value of this Number block or Constant block.
bool.value: Sets and returns the value of this Boolean block.
table.data: Sets and returns the value of this Table block as a DGLux Table.
strLoader.invoke: Causes the string to be loaded. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
strLoader.enabled:
Specifies whether the string loader is enabled.

FALSE
The string does not load.

TRUE
The string loads as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.
strLoader.interval: Specifies how often the string is reloaded automatically, in seconds. A value of 0 means that the string is reloaded on autoRun or invoke only.
strLoader.autoRun: Specifies whether the string is loaded automatically when the page loads.
strLoader.timeout: Specifies how long the block attempts to load the string before the request is canceled.
strLoader.loading: Returns whether the string is currently being loaded.
strLoader.method:
Specifies the HTTP request method for loading the string. In almost all cases, you want GET or POST.

GET
Retrieves the string at the specified URL.

POST
Adds something to the string at the specified URL.
strLoader.headers: Sets the headers for the HTTP request. Use the following syntax: abc=abc&def=def
strLoader.sendCookies: Specifies whether to send the user’s cookie to the URL from which you are retrieving the string. It is safer not to send cookies, but you must send cookies in order to get certain custom information, such as a particular user’s Twitter feed.
strLoader.path: Specifies the URL to load the string from. It can be a DGLux file path relative to the root, or it can be some other URL.
strLoader.data: Sets and returns either the payload for a POST request, or the string to be added to the URL for a GET request.
strLoader.respHeaders: Returns the HTTP response headers received when the string is loaded.
strLoader.output: Returns the string contained in the file. Link this property to the input of a Parser block to create a table.
strLoader.onComplete: Fires when the string finishes loading.
strLoader.error: Returns the error message, if any.
strUploader.invoke: Causes the new file to be created. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
strUploader.enabled:
Specifies whether the string uploader is enabled.

TRUE
A file containing the string is uploaded when this block is invoked.

FALSE
Nothing happens when this block is invoked.
strUploader.path:
Specifies where to upload the new file, relative to the root of this project. Must include a file name and extension.

  • To save to the root, enter /<filename>.<extension>.
  • To save to the assets folder, enter assets/<filename>.<extension>
strUploader.data: Holds the string that becomes the contents of this file.
strUploader.deleteEmptyFile:
Specifies whether to delete the file if data is null.

TRUE
If data is null, nothing happens when this block is invoked.

FALSE
Even if data is null, a file is created when this block is invoked. The file is blank.
strUploader.onComplete: Fires when the file has been created.
strUploader.error: Returns the error message, if any.
listFiles.invoke: Causes the table to be created. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
listFiles.enabled:
Specifies whether the block is enabled.

TRUE
The table is created as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE
The table is not created.
listFiles.interval: Specifies how often the table is automatically generated. A value of 0 means that the table is generated on autoRun or invoke only.
listFiles.autoRun: Specifies whether the table is generated automatically when the page loads.
listFiles.timeout: Specifies how long the block will attempt to create the table before the request is canceled.
listFiles.loading: Returns whether the list is currently loading.
listFiles.path:
Specifies the directory for which to create a table.

  • To list the contents of the root, leave this field blank.
  • To list the contents of the assets folder, drag the folder from the Project panel to this field.
listFiles.filter:
Specifies a string that file names must include in order to be listed. For example, this could be a file extension. Directories are always included in the output if mode is All or Directories. They are not filtered by this property.

  • To list only PNG files, enter png.
  • To list all files, leave this field blank.
listFiles.mode:
Specifies whether the output table lists only files, only directories, or both.

All
Files and directories are listed.

Files
Only files are listed.

Directories
Only directories are listed.
listFiles.output:
Returns a table that lists the contents of the specified directory. The table includes the following fields:

  • name – the filename or directory name.
  • path – the path of the item, relative to the root.
  • isDirectory – TRUE if the item is a directory, FALSE if it is a file.
  • created – 0, if the item is a directory. The serial number for the creation date and time, if it is a file.
  • modified – 0, if the item is a directory. The serial number for the last update date and time, if it is a file.
listFiles.onComplete: Fires when the table is finished loading.
listFiles.error: Returns the error message, if any.
getChildren.path: Specifies the node for which to list children. You can drag the node's icon from the Data panel to this field.
getChildren.output:
Returns a table that lists the children of the specified node. The table includes the following fields:

  • name – the name of the child node
  • path – the full path of the child node
  • hasChildren – TRUE if the child node has children, FALSE if the child node is terminal
  • hasValue – TRUE if the child node is associated with a value, FALSE otherwise
  • hasHistory – TRUE if the child node is associated with a value history, FALSE otherwise
  • type – the data type of the child node, if applicable
  • icon – the absolute file path to the icon that represents the child node
  • unit – the units of the child node, if applicable
  • enum – the names of the enum options, if applicable. For a boolean value, this column holds the strings associated with each value, such as "On" and "Off".
getChildren.error: Returns the error message, if any.
getNode.path: Specifies the absolute location of the node to get metadata for.
getNode.name: name
Returns the name of the node.
getNode.hasChildren: Returns TRUE if the node has children, FALSE if it is terminal.
getNode.hasValue: Returns TRUE if the node is associated with a value, FALSE otherwise.
getNode.hasHistory: Returns TRUE if the node is associated with a value history, FALSE otherwise.
getNode.type: Returns the data type of the node, if applicable.
getNode.icon: Returns the absolute file path to the icon that represents the node.
getNode.unit: Returns the units of the node, if applicable.
getNode.enum: Returns the names of the enum options, if applicable. For a boolean value, this column holds the strings associated with each value, such as "On" and "Off".
getNode.actions: Returns a table of the actions that can be taken on this node, such as overriding it. Each row of this table contains a nested table that lists the parameters of that action. To view a nested table, drag a Table dataflow block into the dataflow window, and drag the cell containing the table onto it.
getNode.error: Returns the error string, if applicable.
listNode.path: Specifies the absolute location of the node to get metadata for. Drag the relevant node from the Data panel to this field.
listNode.mode:
Determines which children of this node are listed.

all
all children

points
only nodes representing data points

actions
only nodes representing actions

nodes
only nodes that are not points or actions
listNode.resolveActions: Determines whether to create an output table describing available actions for this node's children. By default, this property is disabled.
listNode.name: name
Returns the name of the node.
listNode.children: Returns a table that lists the children of the specified node.
listNode.metadata: Returns a table that lists metadata about the specified node.
listNode.actions: Returns a table of the actions that can be taken on this node, such as overriding it. Each row of this table contains a nested table that lists the parameters of that action. To view a nested table, drag a Table dataflow block into the dataflow window, and drag the cell containing the table onto it.
listNode.error: Returns the error message, if any.
projectInfo.projectId: Returns the automatically generated unique ID of this DGLux5 project.
projectInfo.user: Returns the currently logged in user for this session.
projectInfo.superUser: Returns whether the currently logged in user is a Super User.
projectInfo.description: Returns your description of this project. Add a description by selecting Project > Project Properties.
projectInfo.version: Returns the version number you have given to this project. Add a version number by selecting Project > Project Properties.
projectInfo.isDesigner: Returns whether the currently logged in user is a designer for this project.
relativize.path: Sets and returns the current parent directory containing the relative paths.
relativize.output: An instance of the DGLux relativizing service. Click the button to interact with the service. For details, watch the video Introduction to Relativization.
loadHistories.invoke: Causes the histories to be loaded. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
loadHistories.enabled:
Specifies whether the history loader is enabled.

TRUE
The histories load as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE
The histories do not load.
loadHistories.interval: Specifies how often the histories are loaded, in seconds. A value of 0 means that they are reloaded on autoLoad or invoke only.
loadHistories.autoRun: Specifies whether the histories are loaded automatically when the page loads.
loadHistories.timeout: Specifies how long the block attempts to load the histories before the request is canceled.
loadHistories.loading: Returns whether the histories are currently loading.
loadHistories.paths:
Specifies the histories that this block loads. To specify the histories:

  1. Click the Expand icon to open a loadHistories.paths panel.
  2. In the Data panel, click the relevant device or data source.
  3. In the Metrics panel, select a relevant device point, and drag its History icon to the loadHistories.paths panel.
  4. Press Alt + Enter to create a new line.
  5. Repeat steps 2–4 until all paths are entered.
loadHistories.timeRange: Specifies the date and time range to return the histories for. You can click the button and use the date range picker to specify a range.
loadHistories.dataInterval: Specifies the date or time interval between each consecutive pair of data points.
loadHistories.showStatus: Determines whether a status column is included for each history in the output table. Status values report the status of the node data at the time that data was collected, such as "down" or "overridden." This can indicate the reliability of the value.
loadHistories.rollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used. Options are:

  • Avg – the average of all number values for the interval
  • Min – the smallest number value for the interval
  • Max – the largest number value from the interval
  • Sum – the sum of all number values for the interval
  • First – the first value for the interval
  • Last – the last value for the interval
  • Count – the number of non-null values that exist for the interval
loadHistories.missingValue:
Specifies what value to display if there is no data collected for a certain interval.

  • Null – a null value
  • Use previous – the value for the previous timestamp
  • Use next – the value for the next timestamp
  • Interpolate – the average between the previous and next timestamps
  • Zero – zero
loadHistories.header:
Specifies which string is used to name each value column in the output table.

  • Default – the default string "vn"
  • Name – the name of the data node for which this is a history
  • Parent – the name of the data node's parent
  • Parent_Name – the names of both this node and its parent
loadHistories.delta:
Specifies what is in each value column of the output table.

  • None – the value collected at the given time
  • With previous – the difference between the values in this row and the previous one
  • With next – the difference between the values in this row and the next one
loadHistories.output:
Returns a table of the given histories' values. Columns are:

  • timestamp – the time when the data was collected.
  • vn – the first data node's value, or its delta if specified.
  • status (if specified) – the status of the data node at the time of collection. Can sometimes be used to indicate the reliability of the data.
loadValue.path: Specifies the node for which to return information.
loadValue.enabled: Specifies whether the Load Value block updates when the node’s value changes.
loadValue.value: Returns the current value of the node, if enabled is TRUE. Returns the last collected value of the node, if enabled is FALSE.
loadValue.unit: Returns the units of the node.
loadValue.formatted: Returns the formatted value. For example, for a numeric value, it returns a string that includes units. For an enum or boolean value, it returns the string associated with the value.
loadValue.status: Returns the status of the node, if applicable, such as "down" or "overridden." It can indicate the reliability of the value.
loadValue.error: Returns the error message, if any.
loadValue.lastUpdate: Returns a string indicating when the node was last updated.
loadHistory.invoke: Causes the history to be loaded. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
loadHistory.enabled:
Specifies whether the history loader is enabled.

TRUE
The history loads as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE
The history does not load.
loadHistory.interval: Specifies how often the history is loaded, in seconds. A value of 0 means that the history is reloaded on autoLoad or invoke only.
loadHistory.autoRun: Specifies whether the history is loaded automatically when the page loads.
loadHistory.timeout: Specifies how long the loader attempts to load the history before the request is canceled.
loadHistory.loading: Returns whether the history is currently loading.
loadHistory.path: Specifies the history for which to return information.
loadHistory.timeRange: Specifies the date and time range to return the history for. You can click the button and use the date range picker to specify a range.
loadHistory.dataInterval: Specifies the date or time interval between each consecutive pair of data points.
loadHistory.rollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used. Options are:

  • Avg – the average of all number values for the interval
  • Min – the smallest number value for the interval
  • Max – the largest number value from the interval
  • Sum – the sum of all number values for the interval
  • First – the first value for the interval
  • Last – the last value for the interval
  • Count – the number of non-null values that exist for the interval
loadHistory.header:
Specifies which string is used to name the "value" column in the output table.

  • Default – the default string "value"
  • Name – the name of the data node for which this is a history
  • Parent – the name of the data node's parent
  • Parent_Name – the names of both this node and its parent
loadHistory.delta:
Specifies what is in the "value" column of the output table.

  • None – the value collected at the given time
  • With previous – the difference between the values in this row and the previous one
  • With next – the difference between the values in this row and the next one
loadHistory.output:
Returns a table of the given history's values. Columns are:

  • timestamp – the time when the data was collected
  • value – the data node's value, or the delta if specified
  • status – the status of the data node at the time of collection. Can sometimes be used to indicate the reliability of the data.
loadHistory.error: Returns the error string, if any.
jsonpLoader.invoke: Causes the data to be loaded. Only works when enabled is set to TRUE.
jsonpLoader.enabled:
Specifies whether the loader is active.

TRUE
The JSONP data is retrieved as specified by invoke, interval, and autoRun.

FALSE
Nothing happens when this block is invoked.
jsonpLoader.interval: Specifies how often the loader gets data, in seconds.
jsonpLoader.autoRun: Specifies whether the loader gets data automatically. Only works when enabled is set to TRUE.
jsonpLoader.timeout: Specifies how long the loader will attempt to load the string before the request is canceled.
jsonpLoader.loading: Returns whether the block is currently loading data.
jsonpLoader.url: Specifies the location of the JSON string.
jsonpLoader.callback: Specifies the name of the callback function used to retrieve the data. This function must be defined at the URL. You might be able to copy the function name from the URL string, or you might need to find it at the URL.
jsonpLoader.onComplete: Fires when the JSON string is loaded.
jsonpLoader.error: Returns the error message, if any.
gridColumn.!label:
Defines the label to be used as headers for columns controlled by this column editor.

A column editor lets you edit the properties of a group of one or more data grid columns. You can find your column editors in the Outline. To add a column editor, go to the Data Grid properties and click Add Column.
gridColumn.sortable:
Specifies whether the columns affected by this column editor are sortable.

A column editor lets you edit the properties of a group of one or more data grid columns. You can find your column editors in the Outline. To add a column editor, go to the Data Grid properties and click Add Column.
gridColumn.visible:
Defines whether this element is visible. Regardless of value, the element affects layout and is stored in the user's browser memory. Because the element is stored in memory, performance might be affected.

TRUE
This element is visible.

FALSE
This element is not visible, but it still affects layout and is stored in browser memory.
gridColumn.sortingIndicator: Specifies whether a graphic appears in the column that currently sorts the data. The Sorting Indicator property for a Name column editor overrides the Sorting Indicator property for an All column editor.
gridColumn.sortAsc: Sorts the data using this column, in ascending order. Using this trigger changes the sort order to Ascending, under Data Grid properties.
gridColumn.sortDesc: Sorts the data using this column, in descending order. Using this trigger changes the sort order to Descending, under Data Grid properties.
gridColumn.symbol:
Defines the symbol that appears in each cell of the columns affected by this column editor.

If the symbol is in this project, enter the name of the symbol.

To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol.
gridColumn.headerSymbol:
Defines the symbol that appears in the header of the columns affected by this column editor.

If the symbol is in this project, enter the name of the symbol.

To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol.

A column editor lets you edit the properties of a group of one or more data grid columns. You can find your column editors in the Outline. To add a column editor, go to the Data Grid properties and click Add Column.
geoLocation.enabled: Specifies whether the block is currently collecting location data.
geoLocation.latitude: Returns the latitude of the user.
geoLocation.longitude: Returns the longitude of the user.
webDocument.title: title
Specifies the title for this web document. Typically, the user sees this title in the title bar of the browser window or tab. Only works in viewer mode.
webDocument.width: Retrieves the width of the usable portion of the user’s browser window in pixels.
webDocument.height: Retrieves the height of the usable portion of the user’s browser window in pixels.
webDocument.screenWidth: Retrieves the width of the user’s entire screen in pixels.
webDocument.screenHeight: Retrieves the height of the user’s entire screen in pixels.
webDocument.url: Returns the URL of this project.
webDocument.pixelDepth: Retrieves the color depth or bit depth of the user’s screen, as reported by the browser. This is the number of bits used to determine the color of a pixel.
webDocument.pixelRatio: Retrieves the ratio of the width to the height of each pixel on the user’s monitor, as reported by the browser.
webDocument.protocol: Returns whether the project’s URL begins with HTTP or HTTPS.
webDocument.host: Returns the path to the host of this project.
webDocument.pathname: Returns the pathname of this project. This is the portion of the URL after the protocol and host, and before any hash or search strings.
webDocument.inIFrame: Returns whether this instance of the project is within an IFrame.
webDocument.hash: Sets or returns the string to appear after the hash (#) symbol in the URL. This allows you to create deep links and custom experiences based on data, properties, or user interaction. The hash value is saved across sessions and browser windows. The browser’s Back and Forward commands iterate through hash addresses.
webDocument.search: Returns the string that appears after the question mark (?) symbol in the URL. You can bind the search property to a script block and use string functions, such as str.decodeUriComponent(), to parse it into a usable string.
webDocument.language: Retrieves the language code of the browser.
webDocument.platform: Retrieves the platform the browser is running on.
webDocument.userAgent: Retrieves the user–agent string, which identifies the browser and certain system details. It might not be accurate.
webDocument.appName: Retrieves the name of the user’s browser. However, it is not a reliable source of information and often returns "Netscape" for various browsers.
webDocument.appCodeName: Retrieves the internal code name of the browser. However, it is not a reliable source of information and returns "Mozilla" in most cases.
webDocument.appVersion: Retrieves the browser version. It might not be accurate.
webDocument.product: Always returns "Gecko," on any browser. It is not a reliable source of information.
webDocument.productSub: Retrieves the build number of the browser.
webDocument.vendor: Retrieves the vendor name of the browser.
webDocument.vendorSub: Retrieves the version number substring of the vendor information. However, it is not a reliable source of information.
webDocument.isMobile: Returns whether the user is using a mobile device.
webDocument.hasTouch: Returns whether the user’s device has a touch screen.
webDocument.initialScale:
Determines the zoom level at which the project is opened. Only applies to mobile devices.

A value of 1
The application appears at normal scale.

Values greater than 1
The application appears smaller on mobile devices.

Values less than 1
The application appears larger on mobile devices.
webDocument.lockScale:
Determines whether zooming is allowed. Only applies to mobile devices.

TRUE
Zooming is not allowed on mobile.

FALSE
The user can pinch to zoom on mobile.
webDocument.@onBeforePrint: Fires before the browser window contents are sent to the printer dialog. You can use this for changing configuration to prepare for printing.
webDocument.@onAfterPrint: Fires after the browser window contents are sent to the printer dialog. You can use this for reverting changes made using onBeforePrint.
localStorage.key: Sets or returns the key for a key-value pair.
localStorage.global:
Specifies whether this block sets and returns the global or non-global value for the key.

TRUE
This block sets and returns this user’s global value for the key, which stays consistent over any DGLux project.

FALSE
This block sets and returns this user’s non-global value for the key, which applies only to this DGLux project.
localStorage.value: Sets or returns the value for a key-value pair.
iframeMessage.invoke: Causes the message to be sent. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
iframeMessage.enabled:
Specifies whether message sending is enabled.

TRUE
Messages are sent as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE
No messages are sent.
iframeMessage.interval: Specifies how often the message is sent automatically, in seconds. A value of 0 means that it is sent on autoRun or invoke only.
iframeMessage.autoRun: Specifies whether the message is sent automatically when the page loads.
iframeMessage.timeout: Specifies how long the sending attempt will continue before it is canceled, in seconds.
iframeMessage.loading: Returns TRUE if the message is currently being sent, FALSE otherwise.
iframeMessage.message: Holds the message to send, if it is a JSON string. Use this property when sending a message from DGLux.
iframeMessage.key: key and match specify a key-value pair that must be matched somewhere in the JSON message, in order for the message to be sent. Use a value of * for match to accept any value for the specified key. Use these properties when sending a message from DGLux.
iframeMessage.match: key and match specify a key-value pair that must be matched somewhere in the JSON message, in order for the message to be sent. Use a value of * for match to accept any value for the specified key. Use these properties when sending a message from DGLux.
iframeMessage.matchRegExp: Specifies a regular expression that the message must match.
iframeMessage.error: Returns the error message, if any.
exportHtml.invoke: Causes the file to be exported. Only works when enabled is set to TRUE.
exportHtml.enabled:
Specifies whether exporting to HTML is enabled.

TRUE
The file is exported as specified by invoke.

FALSE
The file is not exported.
exportHtml.format: Specifies the file format to download. Select HTML for this property.
exportHtml.filename: Specifies a name for the exported file. If blank, the HTML contents are returned as a string in output and are not downloaded.
exportHtml.output: Returns the contents of the exported file, if no filename is defined.
getViewProperty.objectPath: Specifies the path of the element to get a property for. For the parent of this dataflow block, enter @parent. See Scripting and Syntax.
getViewProperty.field:
Specifies the property whose value you want to retrieve. Use one of these properties:

  • offsetWidth
  • offsetHeight
  • offsetLeft
  • offsetTop
  • scrollWidth
  • scrollHeight
  • scrollLeft
  • scrollTop
  • maxScrollX
  • maxScrollY

For information about these properties, see an HTML reference such as this one.
getViewProperty.invoke: Causes the property value to load.
getViewProperty.output: Returns the value of the property.
and.op:
Specifies the comparison, arithmetic, or text operator to apply to the input values. The operator is used in conjunction with inputs to form an expression that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE.

By default, the op value of an And block is "and".The block will not act as described if you change this property.
and.0:
Specifies one of the input values. All input n values must evaluate to TRUE for the And block to return the then value. For example, "input 0 AND input 1" is a comparison expression. If the values input 0 and input 1 are TRUE, the expression evaluates to TRUE and the And block outputs the then value. Otherwise, if one of the inputs is FALSE, the And block outputs the else value.

If input n is a number, a value of 0 evaluates to FALSE and a value of 1 evaluates to TRUE.

Add more input n properties by clicking the plus sign.
and.then: Specifies the value to return if all of the input properties evaluate to TRUE.
and.else: Specifies the value to return if one or more of the input properties evaluate to FALSE.
and.output: Returns either the then value or the else value. It returns the then value if all of the input n values evaluate to TRUE, and the else value otherwise.
or.op:
Specifies the comparison, arithmetic, or text operator to apply to the input values. The operator is used in conjunction with inputs to form an expression that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE.

By default, the op value of an Or block is "or".The block will not act as described if you change this property.
or.0:
Specifies one of the input values. One or more of the input n values must evaluate to TRUE for the Or block to return the then value. For example, "input 0 OR input 1" is a comparison expression. If input 0 is TRUE and input 1 is FALSE, the expression evaluates to TRUE and the Or block outputs the then value. Otherwise, if both of the inputs are FALSE, the Or block outputs the else value.

If input n is a number, a value of 0 evaluates to FALSE and a value of 1 evaluates to TRUE.

Add more input n properties by clicking the plus sign.
or.then: Specifies the value to return if one or more of the input properties evaluate to TRUE.
or.else: Specifies the value to return if all of the input properties evaluate to FALSE.
or.output: Returns either the then value or the else value. It returns the then value if all of the input n values evaluate to TRUE, and the else value otherwise.
not.input: Specifies a value that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE. If input is a number, a value of 0 evaluates to FALSE and a value of 1 evaluates to TRUE.
not.output: Returns FALSE if the input is TRUE, or returns TRUE if the input is FALSE.
if.op:
Specifies the arithmetic, comparison, or text operator to apply to the input values. It is used in conjunction with input n to form an expression that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE. For example, "input 0 = input 1" is a logical expression. If the value in input 0 is equal to the value in input 1, the expression evaluates to TRUE. Otherwise, the expression evaluates to FALSE.
  • = (equal to) – The expression is true if all input values are equal.
  • > (greater than) – The expression is true if each input value is greater than the value that immediately follows it.
  • < (less than) – The expression is true if each input value is less than the value that immediately follows it.
  • >= (greater than or equal to) – The expression is true if each input value is greater than or equal to the value that immediately follows it.
  • <= (less than or equal to) – The expression is true if each input value is less than or equal to the value that immediately follows it.
  • != (not equal to) – The expression is true if all input values are different. No two can be equal.
  • and – The expression is true if all input values evaluate to TRUE.
  • or – The expression is true if one or more input values evaluate to TRUE.
if.then: Specifies the value to return if the expression evaluates to TRUE. To display the word TRUE, use the logical value TRUE for this parameter. then can be an input from another block or set of blocks, including formulas.
if.else: Specifies the value to return if the expression evaluates to FALSE. To display the word FALSE, use the logical value FALSE for this parameter. else can be an input from another block or set of blocks, including formulas.
if.output: Returns either the then value or the else value. It returns the then value if the expression evaluates to TRUE, and the else value otherwise
case.op: Specifies the arithmetic, comparison, or text operator to apply to the source value and each test value. It is used in conjunction with input and case n to form an expression that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE.
case.input: Specifies the source value that is to be compared with each test value.
case.0: Specifies a test value to compare with the input.
case.1: Specifies the result value if the expression formed by input, operator, and case n is TRUE.
case.else: Specifies the result value to return if none of the expressions evaluates to TRUE.
case.output: Returns either the else value or one of the then n values. If one of the expressions evaluates to TRUE, output returns the then n value for that expression. If none of the expressions evaluates to TRUE, output returns the else value.
hub.0: Sets and returns one of the values watched by this hub.
hub.index: Returns the index of the input n value that was updated most recently. The index is the number in the input's property name. For example, when input 0 updates at 11:00am, and input 1 updates at 11:05am, index is 1 because input 1 updated last.
hub.output: Returns the value of the most recently updated input n property.
eventGate.logOrder:
Specifies how events are logged.

none
Events are not logged.

firstOccurance
The first event for each input n is recorded, beginning with a reset and ending when all fields have been updated at least once. The listener remembers the order in which each input received its first update.

lastOccurance
The last input change for each input n is recorded, beginning with a reset and ending when all fields have been updated at least once. The listener remembers the order in which each input received its most recent update.

all
All input changes are logged, beginning with a reset and ending when all fields have been updated at least once. The order property returns a list of input indexes in the order that the inputs were changed.
eventGate.0: Specifies one of the values that this block listens to.
eventGate.onFinish: Fires an event when all of the inputs have been updated at least once.
eventGate.order: Returns a comma-separated list of integers representing the order in which the input events occurred, as specified by the logOrder property.
script.autoRun: Specifies whether the script is constantly running automatically.
script.script: Specifies the instance of DGScript held by this block. See Scripting and Syntax for more information about creating a script.
script.output: Returns the output of your script.
script.print: Returns a string that is used for errors, other notifications, and debugging.
