stopwatch.enabled: Sets or returns whether the stopwatch is currently running.
stopwatch.interval: Specifies the duration, in seconds, between stopwatch updates. For example, if interval is 0.5 seconds, the stopwatch counts up every 0.5 seconds.
stopwatch.step: Specifies the number that is added to the output with each update. For example, if step is 1, then each time the stopwatch updates, its output increases by 1.
stopwatch.modulo: Specifies the output value before which the stop watch stops or loops. When its output gets as close as possible to the modulo value without reaching it, the stopwatch either stops or loops, depending on the value of the loop property. If the remainder equals the step value, the stopwatch restarts at 0. If the remainder is less than the step value, the remainder is added to 0 when the stopwatch loops.
stopwatch.loop: Determines whether the stopwatch loops when it gets near the modulo value.
stopwatch.reset: Causes the stopwatch to restart at 0.
stopwatch.onLoop: Fires when the stopwatch either loops or stops. It can be used to trigger an action.
changeState.invoke: Activates the state. An event relative to the component, such as onMouseDown, can be bound to invoke, in which case the state is invoked when the event occurs.
changeState.revert: Deactivates the invoked state. An event relative to the component, such as onMouseUp, can be bound to revert, in which case the state is reverted when the event occurs.
changeState.enabled: Determines whether the Set State action is enabled. If the action is disabled, the triggering events do not invoke or revert states.
changeState.duration: Defines the duration of the transition to the defined state, in seconds. Click the "i" icon next to change n to view options for the transition, including animation options.
changeState.durationBack: Defines the duration of the transition when the state is reverted.
changeState.0: Defines a DGLux component whose properties change as part of the state.
changeState.1: Defines the property values change for the component at path n.
mouseEventData.input:
Specifies the event that triggers this block. Make sure that you have selected the correct parent element for the event, and then find the event in the Advanced properties and bind it to this property. Examples include:

  • onClick – The user clicks the element.
  • onClickOff – The user clicks the element (paired with onClickOn).
  • onClickOn – The user clicks the element (paired with onClickOff).
  • onDoubleClick – The user double-clicks the element.
  • onMouseDown – The user presses the mouse button over the element.
  • onMouseEnter – The user moves the cursor onto the element.
  • onMouseLeave – The user moves the cursor off of the element.
  • onMouseMove – The user moves the cursor while it is over the element.
  • onMouseMoveGlobal – The user moves the cursor anywhere on the screen.
  • onMouseUp – The user releases the mouse button over the element.
  • onMouseUpGlobal – The user releases the mouse button anywhere on the screen.
  • onMouseWheel – The user rotates the mouse wheel either up or down.
  • onRightClick – The user right-clicks on the element.
mouseEventData.active: Sets or returns whether this block is currently listening for the specified event.
mouseEventData.event: Returns the event type that this listener heard.
mouseEventData.x: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the left container boundary of the element to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are to the right of the boundary.
mouseEventData.y: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the top container boundary of the element to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are below the top container boundary.
mouseEventData.pageX: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the left page boundary to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are to the right of the left page boundary.
mouseEventData.pageY: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the top page boundary to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are below the top page boundary.
mouseEventData.dragData:
Returns the binary data of the file that is dropped onto this element. To use this property, you must do the following:

  • Enable the droppable Advanced property for this element.
  • Set the dropGroup Advanced property for this element to file_png. You can also replace png with another file extension.
mouseEventData.dragSource:
Returns the ID of the element that is dropped onto this element. To use this property, you must do the following:

  • Enable the droppable Advanced property for this element.
  • Enable the draggable Advanced property for the element to be dragged.
  • Make sure that the dragGroup Advanced property is the same for both elements.
  • Make sure that the dragGroup Advanced property is the same for both elements.
mouseEventData.fileName:
Returns the name of the file that is dropped onto this element. To use this property, you must do the following:

  • Enable the droppable Advanced property for this element.
  • Set the dropGroup Advanced property for this element to file_png. You can also replace png with another file extension.
keyboardEventData.input:
Specifies the event that triggers this block. Make sure that you have selected the correct parent element for the event, and then find the event in the Advanced properties and bind it to this property. Valid events are:

  • onKeyDown – The user depresses a key while the element is in focus.
  • onKeyUp – The user releases the depressed key.
keyboardEventData.active: Sets or returns whether this block is currently listening for the specified event.
keyboardEventData.event: Returns the name of the event type that triggers this block, such as onKeyDown.
keyboardEventData.keyCode: Returns the key code of the last key to undergo key down or key up, whichever was specified. Refer to instances of JavaScript keyCode.
keyboardEventData.ctrl: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Ctrl is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Ctrl was the last key down.
keyboardEventData.alt: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Alt is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Alt was the last key down.
keyboardEventData.shift: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Shift is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Shift was the last key down.
keyboardEventData.meta: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Meta is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Meta was the last key down.
keyboardEventData.filter:
Specifies the keystroke to listen for. This can be a character, or one of the following strings:

  • esc – Escape key
  • enter – Enter or Return key
  • up – Up arrow
  • down – Down arrow
  • left – Left arrow
  • right – Right arrow
  • Combination strings such as "alt+enter"
keyboardEventData.output: Fires when the specified event occurs.
scrollEventData.input: Specifies the event on which the scroll listener starts reporting data. By default, input is an instance of onScrollEvent, so the listener returns data whenever the parent is scrolled. Note that the onScrollEvent property does not exist for all component types.
scrollEventData.active:
Determines whether the block is currently listening.

TRUE
The output properties of the block update whenever the user scrolls.

FALSE
The output properties of the block do not update.
scrollEventData.event: Returns the type of event that triggered this block.
scrollEventData.scrollLeft: Returns the difference in pixels between the left edge of the content and the left edge of the portion currently scrolled to.
scrollEventData.scrollTop: Returns the difference in pixels between the top edge of the content and the top edge of the portion currently scrolled to.
resizeEventData.input: Specifies the event type to listen for. By default, it is the onResize event for this element.
resizeEventData.active: Specifies whether the listener is currently listening.
fastResponse:
Determines whether the fastResponse feature is enabled. Use this feature when you troubleshoot performance speed issues relating to this block.

TRUE
The execution of this block’s event is slightly prioritized, and the queue is kept clear.

FALSE
This is the default behavior.
resizeEventData.event: Fires when the input event occurs and displays the name of the event type. It can be bound to an event.
resizeEventData.offsetWidth: Returns the width of this entire element, in pixels, when the element is resized.
resizeEventData.offsetHeight: Returns the height of this entire element, in pixels, when the element is resized.
resizeEventData.clientWidth: Returns the width of the contents of this element, in pixels, when the element is resized. It includes padding, but it does not include the border or vertical scroll bar.
resizeEventData.clientHeight: Returns the height of the contents of this element, in pixels, when the element is resized. It includes padding, but it does not include the border or horizontal scroll bar.
dragPosition.dragStart: Specifies the event that starts moving the object. Typically, this is the onMouseDown event for the child. In that case, find the event in the child’s Advanced properties, and bind it to this property.
dragPosition.dragEnd: Specifies the event that stops moving the object. Typically, this is the onMouseUp event for the child. In that case, find the event in the child’s Advanced properties, and bind it to this property.
dragPosition.percents: Determines whether the boundsLeft, boundsTop, boundsRight, and boundsBottom properties are pixel values or percent values.
dragPosition.boundsLeft: Specifies the distance from the left boundary of the moved object’s parent to the left boundary of the area available for moving the object. The left edge of the object cannot go beyond this boundary. This can be a pixel value, or a percentage of the parent width. Positive values are inside the parent boundary.
dragPosition.boundsTop: Specifies the distance from the top boundary of the moved object’s parent to the top boundary of the area available for moving the object. The top edge of the object cannot go beyond this boundary. This can be a pixel value, or a percentage of the parent width. Positive values are inside the parent boundary.
dragPosition.boundsRight: Specifies the distance from the right boundary of the moved object’s parent to the right boundary of the area available for moving the object. The right edge of the object cannot go beyond this boundary. This can be a pixel value, or a percentage of the parent width. Positive values are inside the parent boundary.
dragPosition.boundsBottom: Specifies the distance from the bottom boundary of the moved object’s parent to the bottom boundary of the area available for moving the object. The bottom edge of the object cannot go beyond this boundary. This can be a pixel value, or a percentage of the parent width. Positive values are inside the parent boundary.
dragPosition.dragMode:
Specifies restrictions on the direction of movement.

Default
Movement is not restricted.

Vertical
The user can move the object vertically by dragging, but not horizontally.

Horizontal
The user can move the object horizontally by dragging, but not vertically.
dragPosition.isDragging: Returns TRUE if the dragStart event for this block has occurred and the dragEnd event has not occurred yet.
dragSize.dragStart: Specifies the mouse event that starts moving the object. Typically, this is the onMouseDown event for the child. In that case, find the event in the child’s Advanced properties, and bind it to this property.
dragSize.dragEnd: Specifies the event that stops moving the object. Typically, this is onMouseUpGlobal.
dragSize.percents:
Determines whether the minWidth, minHeight, maxWidth, and maxHeight properties are pixel values or percent values.

TRUE
The width values are a percentage of the width of the parent of the element being resized. The height values are a percentage of the height of the parent of the element being resized.

FALSE
The values are in pixels.
dragSize.minWidth: Specifies the smallest width that the element can be resized to, as a pixel value or a percentage of its parent’s width.
dragSize.minHeight: Specifies the smallest height that the element can be resized to, as a pixel value or a percentage of its parent’s height.
dragSize.maxWidth: Specifies the largest width that the element can be resized to, as a pixel value or a percentage of its parent’s width.
dragSize.maxHeight: Specifies the largest height that the element can be resized to, as a pixel value or a percentage of its parent’s height.
dragSize.dragMode:
Specifies restrictions on the direction of resizing.

maxWidth
Resizing is not restricted.

maxHeight
The user can resize the object vertically by dragging, but not horizontally.

dragMode
The user can resize the object horizontally by dragging, but not vertically.
dragSize.isResizing: Returns TRUE if the dragStart event for this block has occurred and the dragEnd event has not occurred yet.
delay.input: Holds the value to deliver after a delay.
delay.delay: Sets the length of the delay, in seconds.
delay.interuptMode:
specifies the behavior of this block in cases where input changes more than once during the duration of a delay.

default
Each input change is moved to output n seconds after it is accepted. Therefore, all changes to input are seen in output.

replace
If the delay timer is not already running, an input change starts it. If another change happens while the timer is running, the timer does not reset. When the timer ends, whatever is in the input is moved to output. Therefore, if multiple changes happen during the same delay, only the last one of those changes is seen in output.

restart
Each input restarts the delay timer. Changes are moved to output only when the timer finishes. Therefore, if multiple changes happen during the same delay, only the last change is returned, and only after a delay that lasts the length of the timer.
delay.output: Returns the input value after the delay.
concat.0: Specifies one of the strings to concatenate.
concat.output: Returns a string formed by concatenating all of the input values.
left.input: Specifies the text string that contains the characters to extract.
left.length: Specifies how many characters to extract.
length.input: Specifies the text to find the length for. Spaces count as characters.
length.output: Returns the number of characters in the input string.
right.input: Specifies the text string that contains the characters to extract.
right.length: Specifies how many characters to extract.
substring.input: Specifies the text string that contains the characters to extract.
substring.start: Determines the position of the first character to extract from the input text. A value of 0 indicates the first character in the input.
substring.length: Specifies the number of characters to extract from the input.
substring.end: Determines the position of the last character to extract from the input text.
replace.input: Specifies the text string in which to replace characters.
replace.regexp: Specifies whether to find strings using a regular expression.
replace.1: Specifies the text to replace find n with.
replace.output: Returns the string with all replacements.
trim.input: Specifies the text to remove spaces from.
trim.output: Returns the input text, with any leading or trailing spaces removed.
add.0: Specifies one of the numbers to add.
add.output: Returns the result of adding all of the input values.
divide.0: input 0 specifies the initial dividend. All other input n values specify divisors. Division is calculated in order, top to bottom.
divide.output: Returns the result of dividing the input values.
factorial.input: Specifies the number to find the factorial for.
factorial.output: Returns the factorial of the input. If the input is not an integer, it is truncated.
log.input: Specifies the number to get the logarithm for.
log.base: Specifies the base for the logarithm.
log.output: Returns the logarithm for the specified input and base.
modulo.quotient: Returns the integer result of the input value divided by the modulo value.
modulo.remainder: Returns the remainder. It always has the same sign as the input, or dividend, value.
multiply.0: Specifies one of the numbers to multiply.
multiply.output: Returns the product of multiplying all of the input values.
power.input: Specifies the value to be raised to an exponent.
power.power: Specifies the exponent to raise input to.
power.output: Returns the result of raising input to the power of power.
root.input: Specifies the value to take the root of.
root.root: Specifies the root to use. For example, a value of 3 calculates a cubic root.
root.output: Returns the result of taking the root-th root of the input value.
scale.inputMin: Specifies the minimum of the original scale.
scale.inputMax: Specifies the maximum of the original scale.
scale.outputMin: Specifies the minimum of the new scale.
scale.outputMax: Specifies the maximum of the new scale.
scale.inputOutOfRange: Returns TRUE if the input is outside the range, FALSE otherwise.
scale.output: Returns the value in the new scale that corresponds to input in the old scale. If input is below the input range, output returns outputMin. If input is above the input range, output returns outputMax.
subtract.0: Specifies one of the numbers to subtract. Subtraction is calculated in order, top to bottom.
subtract.output: Returns the result of subtracting the input values.
abs.input: Specifies the number for which to calculate absolute value.
abs.output: Returns the absolute value of the input.
bound.input: Specifies the number to compare to the range.
bound.min: Specifies the minimum of the range.
bound.max: Specifies the maximum of the range.
bound.inputOutOfRange: Returns TRUE if the input is outside the range, FALSE otherwise.
bound.output: Returns the input number if it is within the range, the min value if input is below the range, or the max value if input is above the range.
round.input: Specifies any real number that you want to round.
round.precision: Specifies the number of digits after the decimal to round the number to. A value of 0, less than 0, or null rounds the number to the nearest integer.
roundUp.input: Specifies any real number that you want rounded up.
roundUp.precision: Specifies the number of digits after the decimal to round the number to. A value of 0, less than 0, or null rounds the number up to the nearest integer.
roundDown.input: Specifies any real number that you want rounded down.
roundDown.precision: Specifies the number of digits after the decimal to round the number to. A value of 0, less than 0, or null rounds the number down to the nearest integer.
gradientMapping.input: Specifies the number to translate to a color in the gradient.
gradientMapping.min: Specifies the minimum of the number scale, corresponding to the left end of the gradient.
gradientMapping.max: Specifies the maximum of the number scale, corresponding to the right end of the gradient.
gradientMapping.output: Returns the color in the gradient that corresponds to the input's position in the number range.
formatNumber.format: Specifies specifies a combination of number format patterns to use. For example, you can format the value to be displayed as "1,050.40" by using the string "#,###.00".
formatNumber.output: Returns the formatted number or string.
parseNumber.input: Specifies the string from which to extract a numeric value.
parseNumber.output: Returns the first numeric value parsed from the input string.
average.0: Specifies one of the values to average.
average.output: Returns the mean of all input values.
max.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
max.output: Returns the largest of the input values.
median.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
median.output: Returns the median of all input values.
min.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
min.output: Returns the smallest of the input values.
mode.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
mode.output: Returns the mode of all input values.
stdDeviation.0: Specifies one of the numbers in the sample.
stdDeviation.output: Returns the standard deviation of the input values.
variance.0: Defines one of the numbers in the set.
variance.output: Returns the variance of the input values.
acos.input: Defines the cosine to get the angle for. Must be between −1 and 1.
acos.output: Returns the arccosine of the input, in degrees.
asin.input: Defines the sine to get the angle for. Must be between −1 and 1.
asin.output: Returns the arcsine of the input, in degrees.
atan.input: Defines the tangent to get the angle for.
atan.output: Returns the arctangent of the input, in degrees.
cos.input: Specifies the angle to get the cosine for, in degrees.
cos.output: Returns the cosine of the input.
cot.input: Specifies the angle to get the cotangent for, in degrees.
cot.output: Returns the cotangent of the input.
toDegree.input: Specifies the angle in radians, to convert to degrees.
toDegree.output: Returns the input value, converted from radians to degrees.
toRadian.input: Specifies the angle in degrees, to convert to radians.
toRadian.output: Returns the input value, converted from degrees to radians.
sin.input: Specifies the angle to get the sine for, in degrees.
sin.output: Returns the sine of the input.
tan.input: Specifies the angle to get the tangent for, in degrees.
tan.output: Returns the tangent of the input.
csvParser.input: Receives the CSV string. It is often the output from a String Loader block.
csvParser.withHeader: Specifies whether the CSV string includes a header row.
csvParser.delimiter: Specifies the character that separates items in the CSV string. Typically this is a comma (,).
csvParser.parseError: Indicates whether the block encountered an error. An error might be caused by improperly formatted input.
csvParser.output: Returns a table parsed from the CSV data.
jsonParser.input: Receives the JSON string. Sometimes it is the output from a String Loader block.
jsonParser.output: Returns a table parsed from the JSON data.
jsonParser.parseError: Indicates whether the block encountered an error. An error might be caused by improperly formatted input.
jsonParser.selector: Specifies the location of the data in the JSON string to parse into a table.
jsonParser.drillDownDepth: specifies how far to drill down into the JSON when extracting data. Data below the drillDownDepth is not included in the output. Only works when a drillDownFilter or flatFilter is specified
jsonParser.drillDownFilter: Specifies what to return for nested tables. Enter * to return all nested tables to the specified drillDownDepth.
jsonParser.flatFilter: Specifies what to return for a flat table. Enter * to return all data to the specified drillDownDepth, in a flat table.
tableColumnMapping.retainColumns: Specifies whether to include the original column as well as the new column in the output table.
tableColumnMapping.1:
Specifies the data to appear in the new column, using JavaScript notation. For example:
  • "=v1+v2" returns the sum of the values in the "v1" column and the "v2" column.
  • "=dateFormat(timestamp,"y-MM-dd")" returns the date in the "timestamp" column with the specified formatting.
  • "=numberFormat(value,"0.00")" returns the value in the "value" column, rounded to the hundredths place.
tableColumnMapping.print: Displays error messages and other notifications for debugging your dataflow.
tableColumnMapping.output: Returns the output table with new columns.
tableSort.input: Receives the table that you want to sort.
tableSort.field: Specifies the name of the table column to sort by.
tableSort.method: Specifies whether to sort values as numbers or strings.
tableSort.order: Specifies whether to sort values in ascending or descending order.
tableFilter.input: Receives the table that you want to filter.
tableFilter.condition: Specifies the condition of the filter. Use Javascript notation. For example, "Damper_Pos==0" returns all rows where the value of the "Damper_Pos" column is 0.
tableFilter.print: Returns output from the condition field. Use for debugging.
tableGroupBy.input: Receives the table whose values you want to group.
tableGroupBy.baseColumn: Specifies the name of the table column in which to group values.
tableGroupBy.nestedData: Specifies whether to keep the original rows in a new column of the output table as nested tables. You can view the child table data by binding a cell containing a table to a Table dataflow block.
tableGroupBy.includeBlankValue: Specifies whether to include a row for a blank value of the baseColumn, if a blank value exists.
tableGroupBy.0: Specifies the name of an input table column to group.
tableGroupBy.1:
specifies how to return values in column n for each baseColumn value.

first
Returns the first value in the group.

last
Returns the last value in the group.

average
Returns the average of all number values in the group. Non-number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

sum
Returns the sum of all number values in the group. If there are no number values, returns 0.

max
Returns the largest number value in the group. If there are no number values, returns null.

min
Returns the smallest number in the group. Non-number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

count
Returns the number of values in the group.

concat
Returns all values in the group, separated by commas. Duplicate values are listed.

concatUnique
Returns all unique values in the group, separated by commas. Duplicate values are not listed.

tableUnion
Returns a table of values.
tableGroupBy.2: Specifies the label for the column of grouped column n values.
tableGroupBy.output: Returns the output table. It contains one row for each unique value in baseColumn.
tableJoin.input1: Specifies the first table to join.
tableJoin.input2: Specifies the second table to join.
tableJoin.field1: Specifies the name of the key column from the input1 table.
tableJoin.field2: Specifies the name of the key column from the input2 table.
tableJoin.join:
Determines the method of joining.

Left
All rows from input1 are included. Rows from input2 are merged when the column2 value matches a column1 value.

Right
All rows from input2 are included. Rows from input1 are merged when the column1 value matches a column2 value.

Inner
Rows are included and merged only when the values in column1 and column2 are the same.

Full
All rows from both tables are included, and the rows are merged if the values of column1 and column2 are the same.

Union
All rows from both tables are included in a new table. Rows are not merged.
tableJoin.renameColumns:
Determines the naming in the output table for columns that come from input2. Make sure to rename columns if you don’t want them combined. Use this syntax:

column1:newName
column2:newName

Press Alt + Enter to create a new line.
tablePage.input: Receives the table for which you want to create paging.
tablePage.pageSize: Specifies the number of rows per page.
tablePage.start: Specifies the row index to start paging on. Rows before this index are omitted from the output.
tablePage.nextPage: Advances the output table to the next page.
tablePage.prevPage: Changes the output table to the previous page.
tablePage.firstPage: Changes the output table to the first page.
tablePage.lastPage: Advances the output table to the last page.
tablePage.currentPage: Sets or returns the current page.
tablePage.totalPage: Returns the total number of pages for this table.
tablePage.output: Returns the portion of the input table specified by the paging parameters.
tableRollup.input: Receives the table in which you want to roll up values.
tableRollup.interval:
Specifies the length of the range to roll up. It can be any of the following.
  • One minute
  • Five minutes
  • Ten minutes
  • Fifteen minutes
  • Twenty minutes
  • Thirty minutes
  • Hour
  • Two hours
  • Three hours
  • Four hours
  • Six hours
  • Twelve hours
  • Day
  • Two days
  • Week
  • Month
  • Year
tableRollup.dateColumn: Specifies the name of the table column that holds the dates.
tableRollup.valueColumn: Specifies the name of the table column that holds the values to be rolled up.
tableRollup.valueRollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used.

First
Returns the first value for the interval.

Last
Returns the last value for the interval.

Average
Returns the average of all number values for the interval. Non-number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

Sum
Returns the sum of all number values for the interval. If there are no number values, returns 0.

Max
Returns the largest number value from the interval. If there are no number values, returns null.

Min
Returns the smallest number value for the interval. Non-number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

Count
Returns the number of values that exist for the interval. Null values are not included.

Concat
Returns all values for the interval, separated by commas. Includes duplicate values.

ConcatUnique
Returns all unique values for the interval, separated by commas. Duplicate values are not included.
tableRollup.roundTime:
Specifies whether to force all intervals to start at a round number.

TRUE
Intervals start at a round number. For example, if interval is "day", all intervals start at midnight. If interval is "five minutes", all intervals start at a multiple of five minutes past the hour.

FALSE
The first interval starts at the first timestamp, and intervals are appended accordingly. For example, if interval is "day" and the first value is 2015/07/19T08:01:19, then all intervals begin at T08:01:19.
tableAggregation.input: Receives the table in which you want to aggregate values.
tableAggregation.column: Specifies the name of the table column.
tableAggregation.method:
Specifies the type of aggregation.

First
Returns the first value in the column.

Last
Returns the last value in the column.

Average
Returns the average of all number values in the column. Non-number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

Sum
Returns the sum of all number values in the column. If there are no number values, returns 0.

Max
Returns the maximum number value in the column. If there are no number values, returns null.

Min
Returns the minimum number value in the column. Non-number values are treated as null and are not included in the calculation.

Count
Returns the number of values in the column. Null values are not included.

Concat
Returns all values in the column as a comma-separated list. Duplicate values are included.

Concat unique
Returns all unique values in the column as a comma-separated list. Duplicate values are not included.

Table Union
If the data type of the input column is "table", performs a union join on the nested tables and returns the joined table.
tableAggregation.output: Returns the output string as determined by the method parameter.
tableSelectRows.input: Receives the table from which you want to select rows.
tableSelectRows.indexes: Specifies the rows in the input table to select, as comma-separated values.
tableSelectRows.output: Returns a new table. It contains only the rows at the specified indexes.
tableGetColumns.input: Receives the table from which you want to get column names.
tableGetColumns.output: Returns the output table. It contains a row for each column in the input table.
tableRowCells.table: Receives the table from which you want to get values.
tableRowCells.row: Specifies a row index in the input table.
tableRowCells.0: Specifies a column name in the input table
tableRowCells.1:
Sets or returns the cell value at the specified row and column n.

Although value n is an Input/Output property, changing it writes to the data source only if the data source is a Table block in the dataflow. For other data sources, changing the value does nothing.
tableTranspose.input: Receives the table that you want to transpose.
tableTranspose.ignoreColumns: Specifies the names of columns in the input table to ignore when transposing, as comma-separated values.
tableTranspose.headerColumn: Specifies the column from the input table to use as headers in the output table.
tableTranspose.includeHeaders: Specifies whether the header row from the input table is included as a column in the output table.
tableTranspose.headerPrefix: Specifies the text string to include before the column number for each column header in the output table. It only works when the headerColumn property is null.
datetime.year: Specifies the year. Can include one to four digits.
datetime.month: Specifies the month of the year, from 1 to 12 (January to December). Can be a positive or negative integer. See the DGLux5 wiki for details.
datetime.day: Specifies the day of the month, from 1 to 31. Can be a positive or negative integer. See the DGLux5 wiki for details.
datetime.hour: Specifies the hour of the day, from 1 to 24. Can be a positive or negative integer. See the DGLux5 wiki for details.
datetime.minute: Specifies the minute of the hour, from 1 to 60. Can be a positive or negative integer. See the DGLux5 wiki for details.
datetime.second: Specifies the second of the minute, from 1 to 60. Can be a positive or negative integer. See the DGLux5 wiki for details.
datetime.millisecond: Specifies the millisecond of the second, from 1 to 1000. Can be a positive or negative integer. See the DGLux5 wiki for details.
datetime.isUTC: Determines whether to use UTC. By default, DGLux will use your computer's time zone when converting to serial number. Set the isUTC boolean to TRUE if you want to use UTC instead.
datetime.output: Returns the sequential serial number that represents a particular date and time.
dateFormat.input: Specifies the serial number or any supported date time string as outlined in Scripting and Syntax.
dateFormat.format: Specifies a combination of desired dateFormat patterns. For example, you can format the date to be displayed as "Mon, Jan 5, 2015" with this format string: "E, MMM d, yyyy".
dateFormat.output: Returns a DateTime string created from the specified input string and format.
parseDateTime.input: Specifies the serial number or any supported date time string as outlined here.
parseDateTime.month: Returns the month of the year as a number from 1 to 12.
parseDateTime.day: Returns the day of the month as a number from 1 to 31.
parseDateTime.hour: Returns the hour of the day as a number from 1 to 24.
parseDateTime.minute: Returns the minute of the hour as a number from 1 to 60.
parseDateTime.second: Returns the second of the minute as a number from 1 to 60.
parseDateTime.millisecond: Returns the millisecond of the second as a number from 1 to 1000.
parseDateTime.weekday: Returns the day of the week as a number from 1 to 7. The number 1 represents Sunday, and the number 7 represents Saturday.
dateMath.input: Specifies the serial number or any supported date time string as outlined here.
dateMath.op:
pecifies whether Date Math performs "Before" calculations or "After" calculations on the input date.

After
The values of the other inputs are added to the input value.

Before
The values of the other inputs are subtracted from the input value.
dateMath.year: Specifies the number of years to add or subtract, as a number with one to four digits.
dateMath.month: Specifies the number of months to add or subtract.
dateMath.day: Specifies the number of days to add or subtract.
dateMath.hour: Specifies the number of hours to add or subtract.
dateMath.minute: Specifies the number of minutes to add or subtract.
dateMath.second: Specifies the number of seconds to add or subtract.
dateMath.millisecond: Specifies how many milliseconds to add or subtract.
dateMath.output: Returns the result of adding or subtracting the other inputs with the input value, depending on the op value.
